That's simply invalid XML, `xmltodict` will not attempt to fix it for you. It's easy to work around, though:

``` python
def rootlessparse(doc):
    return xmltodict.parse('<root>{0}</root>'.format(doc))['root']

rootlessparse('''
<test>0</test>
<another>1</another>
''') # this returns {u'test': u'0', u'another': u'1'}
```

that's invalid xml, any sane xml parser should fail with it. you should escape your strings.

``` python
>>> xmltodict.parse('<x>&</x>')
Traceback (most recent call last):
  ...
xml.parsers.expat.ExpatError: not well-formed (invalid token): line 1, column 4
>>> xmltodict.parse('<x>&</x>')
{u'x': u'&'}
```

I'm not sure I understand. Can you explain a bit further, with a code example if possible?

If a post processor is used, it's no longer possible to unparse the provided OrderedDict back into the exact same XML. For instance: ``` python def postprocessor(path, key, value): try: return key + ':int', int(value) except (ValueError, TypeError): return key, value >>> xmltodict.parse('12x', postprocessor=postprocessor) OrderedDict([(u'a', OrderedDict([(u'b:int', [1, 2]), (u'b', u'x')]))]) ``` if we unparse this data, we are not returned the original XML: ``` python >>> processed = xmltodict.parse('12x', postprocessor=postprocessor) >>> xmltodict.unparse(processed) u'\n12x' ``` It would be useful to have a preprocessor hook that would enable this behavior: ``` python def preprocessor(foo, bar): try: foo except: return bar >>> processed = xmltodict.parse('12x', postprocessor=postprocessor) >>> xmltodict.unparse(processed, preprocessor=preprocessor) u'\n12x' ``` This feature, combined with properly written processors, would allow round tripping with xmltodict.

I would, because I'm a human being and I know `children` is the plural form of `child`. The only thing `xmltodict` knows, though, is that it has only found one value for the `child` node (same way as with `root`, `children` and `name`), so there's no need for iterable objects there.

You can easily work around this by using a custom `dict_constructor` that always starts off with empty lists as values, i.e.:

``` python
from collections import defaultdict
xmltodict.parse(xml, dict_constructor=lambda *args, **kwargs: defaultdict(list, *args, **kwargs))
```

This is a good workaround.

Given the following pseudo-XML example:

``` xml
<doc>
    <item>Item1</item>
    <item>Item2</item>
    <item>Item3</item>
    <item>Item4</item>
</doc>
```

I'd like to retrieve _only_ Item2 and Item4.  If I return False parsing is terminated.

I get it. In this case, you should use a `postprocessor`, not the streaming mode.
The postprocessing function gets three arguments in (`path`, `key` and `value`) and must return a `(key, value)` tuple or `None` to skip the node altogether.

If you want to skip odd `<item>`s, you should do something like this:

``` python
xml = '''
<doc>
    <item>Item1</item>
    <item>Item2</item>
    <item>Item3</item>
    <item>Item4</item>
</doc>'''

class SkipOddValues:
    def __init__(self, key):
        self.key = key
        self.count = 0

    def __call__(self, path, key, value):
        if key != self.key:
            return key, value
        self.count += 1
        if self.count % 2 == 1:
            return None
        else:
            return key, value

doc = xmltodict.parse(xml, postprocessor=SkipOddValues('item'))
```

I like the idea: pretty-printing is surely a useful feature. However, I'm not sure I like the approach. You are extending `XMLGenerator` but then completely overriding the core `startElement()`, `endElement()` and `characters()` methods. I would bet there are corner cases that the new implementation doesn't cover but `XMLGenerator` does.

I think the right, robust way to do this is by leaving `XMLGenerator` untouched and modifying our own `_emit` function to pass a `depth` parameter to itself and call `content_handler.ignorableWhitespace()` appropriately.

You should the `json` module to turn it into JSON, e.g.:

``` python
> import xmltodict
>>> foo = xmltodict.parse("""<?xml version="1.0" ?>
...         <person>
...           <name>john</name>
...           <age>20</age>
...         </person>""")
>>> print json.dumps(foo)
{"person": {"name": "john", "age": "20"}}
```

`OrderedDict` is just a `dict` that preserves key order (makes sure that if you round-trip that object to XML, `name` will always come before `age`).

This is a duplicate of #14. Unfortunately, there is no easy way for `xmltodict` to know beforehand which elements are supposed to be `list`s and which are supposed to be single elements. I can think of 2 workarounds for this:
- The `dict_constructor` approach I described in #14, in which case _all_ values will be `list`s (`doc['root'][0]['abc'][1]['tr'] == ['four']`).
- Writing your own `postprocessor` that cherry picks the values that should be converted to lists in your particular type of document.

I don't see the issue here. If you want to compare two documents, it doesn't make a difference at all whether you use `OrderedDict` or a regular `dict`: ``` python >>> from collections import OrderedDict >>> OrderedDict([('a', 'b')]) == {'a': 'b'} True ``` However, if you don't want to use `OrderedDict`s at all and just want to use regular `dict`s all over, it's easy to override the default behavior using the `dict_constructor` parameter: ``` python >>> import xmltodict >>> xmltodict.parse('b', dict_constructor=dict) {u'a': u'b'} ```

It's not incorrect, it's just one of the possible ways of handling lists. What matters is that `unparse()` is consistent with `parse()` and roundtrips correctly.

I understand that this way of handling lists can be annoying for your use case, but if I changed xmltodict to your convenience I still wouldn't be able to make everyone happy. If this:

``` python
{
  'response': {
    'versions': [
      {'version': 1},
      {'version': 2}
    ]
  }
}
```

`unperse`s to:

``` xml
<response>
  <versions>
    <version>1</version>
    <version>2</version>
  </versions>
</response>
```

Then it means that this:

``` xml
<settings>
  <bind>localhost</bind>
  <bind>192.168.1.1</bind>
  <port>8080</port>
</settings>
```

has to `parse` to:

``` python
{
  'settings': [
    {'bind': 'localhost'},
    {'bind': '192.168.1.1'},
    {'port': '8080'}
  ]
}
```

Which would be a pain to use, compared with this, which is the current behavior:

``` python
{
  'settings': {
    'bind': ['localhost', '192.168.1.1'],
    'port': '8080'
  }
}
```

That's what the `strip_whitespace` argument is for: deciding whether to strip whitespace or not. It defaults to `True`, but if you pass `False` you get what you're looking for:

``` python
>>> xml = '''<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
... <service>
...     <key>
...         <name>SEPARATOR</name>
...         <value>	</value>
...     </key>
... </service>
... '''
>>> doc = xmltodict.parse(xml, strip_whitespace=False)
>>> doc['service']['key']['value']
u'\t'
```

While I do appreciate it and thank you for taking the time to write this long proposal, I do not see something like this happening to `xmltodict`.

`xmltodict` aims to be a very simple library that implements **just one** of the many possible ways one can map XML to and from JSON-like structures. This particular mapping works fine for some simple use cases, but unfortunately it does not for other more complex ones, such as the ones you mention. It does not feature type coercion, meta processing directives nor attribute sniffing. This is by design.

I do understand that your proposed features must make a lot of sense in your context, so I would like to encourage you to either:
- Implement all this and submit a Pull Request, so I can review the impact of this added complexity on code maintainability, backwards compatibility and usefulness for the originally intended, simple scenarios. I promise to reconsider my position once I see the implementation and tests.
- Fork `xmltodict` and build your own XML processing library on top of it.

You can hack through this issue by replacing the tag in the response string before passing to xmltodict parser.

``` xml
"<someTag>bar foo</someTag>"
```

and you do not want it to be parsed, you can try 


The problem is not related with `xmltodict` at all, it's just that you are not building the `OrderedDict`s correctly.

The constructor takes a list of key/value tuples as parameter, but you are passing a `dict` instead, which has already lost the ordering information before the `OrderedDict` is even created. Please have a look at the [official documentation](https://docs.python.org/2/library/collections.html#ordereddict-examples-and-recipes).

OK, that's because Python 2.6 uses dict behind the scenes: ``` try: # pragma no cover from collections import OrderedDict except ImportError: # pragma no cover try: from ordereddict import OrderedDict except ImportError: OrderedDict = dict ``` The outcome of such tests is pure luck. A quick fix is to modify asserts to expect both `1` and `2` to be present in XML but not in any particular order. I'm sure there is a better way to write asserts about XML contents though. _Edit:_ Or actually just provide ordereddict for both tox and travis as a dependency.

Just now I've read the source of xmltodict, and it seems that the author thought of this earlier and it's possible to use `defusedexpat`: ``` import defusedexpat xmltodict.parse('hello', expat=defusedexpat.pyexpat) ``` So, the question is, why not make defusedexpat a default version of expat?

``` python
# /usr/bin/env python
# filename: xml2dict_IS87.py 
import xmltodict
import json
import difflib
import sys

XMLSTRING="""<?xml version="1.0" encoding="ISO-8859-1"?>
<BroadsoftDocument protocol="OCI" xmlns="C">
  <userId xmlns="">someuserid!</userId>
  <command xsi:type="UserOutgoingCallingPlanOriginatingModifyRequest" xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance">;
    <userId>12345678</userId>
    <useCustomSettings>true</useCustomSettings>
    <userPermissions>
      <group>Allow</group>
      <local>Allow</local>
      <tollFree>Allow</tollFree>
      <toll>Allow</toll>
      <international>Allow</international>
      <operatorAssisted>Allow</operatorAssisted>
      <chargeableDirectoryAssisted>Allow</chargeableDirectoryAssisted>
      <specialServicesI>Allow</specialServicesI>
      <specialServicesII>Allow</specialServicesII>
      <premiumServicesI>Disallow</premiumServicesI>
      <premiumServicesII>Disallow</premiumServicesII>
      <casual>Disallow</casual>
      <urlDialing>Allow</urlDialing>
      <unknown>Allow</unknown>
    </userPermissions>
  </command>
</BroadsoftDocument>
"""

EXPECTED="""{
  "BroadsoftDocument": {
    "@protocol": "OCI", 
    "userId": "someuserid!", 
    "command": {
      "@type": "UserOutgoingCallingPlanOriginatingModifyRequest", 
      "userId": "12345678", 
      "useCustomSettings": "true", 
      "userPermissions": {
        "group": "Allow", 
        "local": "Allow", 
        "tollFree": "Allow", 
        "toll": "Allow", 
        "international": "Allow", 
        "operatorAssisted": "Allow", 
        "chargeableDirectoryAssisted": "Allow", 
        "specialServicesI": "Allow", 
        "specialServicesII": "Allow", 
        "premiumServicesI": "Disallow", 
        "premiumServicesII": "Disallow", 
        "casual": "Disallow", 
        "urlDialing": "Allow", 
        "unknown": "Allow"
      }, 
      "#text": ";"
    }
  }
}"""

PARSED = xmltodict.parse(XMLSTRING.strip(), process_namespaces=True, namespaces={'C':None, 'xsi':None, 'http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance':None})

RESULT = json.dumps(PARSED, indent=2)

if RESULT != EXPECTED:
    print('EXPECTED')
    print(EXPECTED)
    print
    print('RESULT')
    print(RESULT)

    print
    print('DIFF')
    for line in difflib.unified_diff(RESULT.splitlines(1), EXPECTED.splitlines(1), fromfile="RESULT", tofile="EXPECTED"):
        sys.stdout.write(line)
    sys.exit(1)
```

``` python
  <command xsi:type="UserOutgoingCallingPlanOriginatingModifyRequest" xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance">;
  </command>
</BroadsoftDocument>
"""

EXPECTED="""{
  "BroadsoftDocument": {
    "@protocol": "OCI", 
    "command": {
      "@type": "UserOutgoingCallingPlanOriginatingModifyRequest"
      }, 
      "#text": ";"
    }
  }
}"""

PARSED = xmltodict.parse(XMLSTRING.strip(), process_namespaces=True, namespaces={'C':None, 'xsi':None, 'http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance':None})

RESULT = json.dumps(PARSED, indent=2)

if RESULT != EXPECTED:
    print('EXPECTED')
    print(EXPECTED)
    print
    print('RESULT')
    print(RESULT)

    print
    print('DIFF')
    for line in difflib.unified_diff(RESULT.splitlines(1), EXPECTED.splitlines(1), fromfile="RESULT", tofile="EXPECTED"):
        sys.stdout.write(line)
    sys.exit(1)
```

So I delved deeper into asyncio, coroutines, generators with the goal to turn callbacks into generators and unfortunately without success. The problem is that on one end I need a generator (pulling data from the source) and on the other end I have a coroutine (pushing data from the source). I need to use asyncio event loop to start both the producer and consumer but it doesn't allow me to use a for loop for driving the computation. In order to synchronize both I tried to use a Queue but the problem is then that putting into the queue is a coroutine and it has to be wrapped into a task, which gets executed later in the loop, thus the computation is not lazy at all. What I'd like is that putting an item into the queue in the callback blocks and switches the execution to the consumer.

After many tries I've created a thread on stackoverflow, so possibly someone more experienced might help us: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/29724273/transform-callbacks-to-generator-in-python

At least I tried to get the code with threads working. After a lot of fiddling with the producer-consumer pattern it works. The producer can be notified when the generator was closed and finish the thread. So it is possible to break from within the for loop and the producer thread finishes correctly. The trick to coordinate the consumer and producer is to use two singleton queues (one for requests and the other for responses).

A generator can either finish correctly or be closed. Eg. when break occurs before the generator completes. In this case we can signal to the producer, that it should finish. The failing test case was a bit strange usage since since it neither completely iterated the generator not closed it. It would correspond to a situation when processing one item hangs. A possible behavior is to finish the producer thread after some time of consumer inactivity.

The new code seems to work ok. I'll try to clean it up a bit and commit it tomorrow.

I was just planning to raise this issue after hitting it in a new project I'm doing. My initial reaction to 2. was 'yes, exactly'.

I've thought about it a bit more though, and realize that in nested situations this would be a real mess. So for example this:-

``` xml
<parent>
    <sub>
        <child>some text</child>
        <child>other text</child>
    </sub>
</parent>
```

would require this:-

``` python
children = parse_result['parent'][0]['sub'][0]['child']
```

That being said, an optional argument to parse as suggested would be welcome as a convenience. Better yet if it only applies to leaves and not intermediates.

What you could do is to nominate particular elements which should always generate lists, e.g.

```
xmltodict.parse(xml, force_list=set('child'))
```

This is the approach taken by Perl's XML::Simple with the [ForceArray](http://search.cpan.org/~grantm/XML-Simple-2.20/lib/XML/Simple.pm#ForceArray_=>_[_names_]_#_in_-_important) setting.

A problem with this is that if the `<children>` element is empty, it's not going to give you an empty list of `{"child": []}`. This is due to how xmltodict groups elements at a lower level, i.e. it's not `children` which is a list, but `child` which is a list.

So to work with xmltodict, I think you need to specify the enclosing element as well:

```
xmltodict.parse(xml, force_list={'children': 'child'})
```

Implies: "if you see a `<children>` element then always build a `<child>` with empty list underneath it".  Any actual `<child>` elements will then be added to that list.

Aside: there is a related but different problem, which is dealing with a heterogenous sequence of repeating elements. For example:

```
<stuff>
  <foo>.1.</foo>
  <bar>.2.</bar>
  <bar>.3.</bar>
  <foo>.4.</foo>
  <bar>.5.</bar>
</stuff>
```

At the moment you get:

```
OrderedDict([(u'stuff', OrderedDict([(u'foo', [u'.1.', u'.4.']), (u'bar', [u'.2.', u'.3.', u'.5.'])]))])
```

which loses the ordering relationship between the `foo` and `bar` elements.

This would have to be dealt with differently. For example:

```
xmltodict.parse(xml, force_list={'stuff': True})
```

could mean that `<stuff>` is forced to have a list of children, and that this list should contain repeated elements rather than grouped elements.  I don't know how practical that is to implement though.  And it would probably have implications for unparse.

What you could do is to nominate particular elements which should always generate lists, e.g.

```
xmltodict.parse(xml, force_list=set('child'))
```

This is the approach taken by Perl's XML::Simple with the [ForceArray](http://search.cpan.org/~grantm/XML-Simple-2.20/lib/XML/Simple.pm#ForceArray_=>_[_names_]_#_in_-_important) setting.

A problem with this is that if the `<sub>` element is empty, it's not going to give you an empty list of `{"child": []}`. This is due to how xmltodict groups elements at a lower level, i.e. it's not `sub` which is a list of child elements, but `child` which is a list.

So to work with xmltodict, I think you need to specify the enclosing element as well:

```
xmltodict.parse(xml, force_list={'sub': 'child'})
```

Implies: "if you see a `<sub>` element then always build a `<child>` with empty list underneath it".  Any actual `<child>` elements will then be added to that list, and will be consistent for 0, 1 or more elements.

Aside: there is a related but different problem, which is dealing with a heterogenous sequence of repeating elements. For example:

```
<stuff>
  <foo>.1.</foo>
  <bar>.2.</bar>
  <bar>.3.</bar>
  <foo>.4.</foo>
  <bar>.5.</bar>
</stuff>
```

At the moment you get:

```
OrderedDict([(u'stuff', OrderedDict([(u'foo', [u'.1.', u'.4.']), (u'bar', [u'.2.', u'.3.', u'.5.'])]))])
```

which loses the ordering relationship between the `foo` and `bar` elements.

This would have to be dealt with differently. For example:

```
xmltodict.parse(xml, force_list={'stuff': True})
```

could mean that `<stuff>` is forced to have a list of children, and that this list should contain repeated elements rather than grouped elements.  I don't know how practical that is to implement though.  And it would probably have implications for unparse.

There is an issue where the list may be empty. Suppose you have:

```
        <servers>
        </servers>
```

then this parses as:

```
{
    "servers": None
}
```

Then the user code needs to look something like this:

```
        if data['servers']:
            servers = data['servers']['server']
        else:
            servers = []
        for server in servers:
            print server['name'], server['os']
```

Or more obtusely:

```
        for server in (data['servers'] or {'server':[]})['server']:
            print server['name'], server['os']
```

To fix this would require indicating the expected child for each parent. What do people think about `force_list={'servers': 'server'}` ? This would mean:
1. A `<servers>` tag would always generate a `"server": [...]` child in the parsed output, with zero or more elements
2. Conversely, a random `<server>` tag would _not_ be forced to a list unless it is directly inside a `<servers>` tag

It covers it for me, though not hard to imagine situations where this would be a pain (as in my 22 Sep comment). However since this would not be default behaviour, callers would be expected to deal with that gracefully.

I like candlerb's suggestion but that would both be more work and probably more brittle as well (hence harder to properly test).

The guiding principle behind the design of xmltodict is to implement **one simple mapping** between XML and nested dict+list+string structures resembling what you would get from a JSON document, no more, no less. I have no intention of making xmltodict a full fledged XML processing framework and I think that features like the one proposed in this ticket come at the expense of the library's ease of use and code simplicity/maintainability.

IMHO, if you're hitting xmltodict's limitations, you should use XPath over the excellent [lxml](http://lxml.de/).

Of course I could be wrong, if so please prove it with a pull request that I'll be glad to review and merge as long as the library remains easy to use, simple and maintainable.

When I try your fix, it still does not work. > > > import xmltodict > > > val = 'Hi my name is Bob' > > > strings = [{"@name": "some_html", "#text": val}] > > > xmld = {"resources": {"string": strings}} > > > xml = xmltodict.unparse(xmld, pretty=True) > > > xml > > > '\n\n\t<a href="http://www.space.com">Hi my name is Bob</a>\n' How can I get the CDATA text at the end without the escapes ?
It's just not possible to do this with xmltodict, it's not what the library is intended for.

FWIW, I was able to accomplish what I needed with this change:

**\* xmltodict.py.orig   2016-03-28 13:37:00.098508399 -0500
--- xmltodict.py        2016-03-28 16:11:52.053726618 -0500

---

**\* 362,368 ****
--- 362,371 ----
                    attr_prefix, cdata_key, depth+1, preprocessor,
                    pretty, newl, indent)
          if cdata is not None:
-             # Output the CDATA start/end tags explicity
-             content_handler._write(r"<![CDATA[")
            content_handler.characters(cdata)
-             content_handler._write(r"]]>")
        if pretty and children:
            content_handler.ignorableWhitespace(depth \* indent)
        content_handler.endElement(key)

I understand now that xmltodict notion of cdata is different from XML's notion of CDATA. The above hack simply does not work because any and all character data gets encapsulated by XML's CDATA strings.

The solution I found is to do the following:
- Encapsulate any user CDATA with the XML CDATA strings.
- Use xmltodict.unparse() to write the data to a string
- Use xml.sax.saxutils.unescape() to reconvert the entity references back.

AFAIK the order of children has no meaning in "pure" XML. A semantically valid option may be, if that's acceptable to you, to add an attribute "@position" or "@order" to the elements you want to have in some sequence.

This information would then be available for querying/sorting/filtering/whatever, and since the elements would have difference sequence attributes they would not be considered as duplicates by the parser (and thus not "merged").
Some services do require certain order of children unfortunately.

Hi @timmwagener 
`xmltodict` tries to preserve order whenever possible: adds elements to lists in the order they're received from the parser and uses `OrderedDict` instead of plain `dict` if available. If you do find cases where order isn't preserved, please file them as a bug.

I've also noticed there's a "force_list" option you can use in this case:

https://github.com/martinblech/xmltodict/blob/master/tests/test_xmltodict.py#L252

```
You can use the force_list argument to force lists to be created even
    when there is only a single child of a given level of hierarchy. The
    force_list argument is a tuple of keys. If the key for a given level
    of hierarchy is in the force_list argument, that level of hierarchy
    will have a list as a child (even if there is only one sub-element).
    The index_keys operation takes precendence over this. This is applied
    after any user-supplied postprocessor has already run.

        For example, given this input:
        <servers>
          <server>
            <name>host1</name>
            <os>Linux</os>
            <interfaces>
              <interface>
                <name>em0</name>
                <ip_address>10.0.0.1</ip_address>
              </interface>
            </interfaces>
          </server>
        </servers>

        If called with force_list=('interface',), it will produce
        this dictionary:
        {'servers':
          {'server':
            {'name': 'host1',
             'os': 'Linux'},
             'interfaces':
              {'interface':
                [ {'name': 'em0', 'ip_address': '10.0.0.1' } ] } } }

        `force_list` can also be a callable that receives `path`, `key` and
        `value`. This is helpful in cases where the logic that decides whether
        a list should be forced is more complex.

```

Martin, I did read the conversation and understood it.  The point, in other terms, is that force_list should be the default behavior.  Because of the nature and intent of xml, it is much more likely that at SOME point in your XML document, you'll have a structure that can have 1 or more child nodes.  Without uniformly handling "1 child node" and "more than 1 child nodes" use cases, you have to write ugly code that has different implementations for "1" or "more than 1" child node use cases whereas a single case would be fine to handle both.  The problem is further extended if, link in the EVENT structure I used, you need to examine the data.  If the EVENT node has a varying number of child nodes, it is difficult to determine if you've iterated over all the EVENT child nodes without an iterator, especially since python doesn't have a convenient hasNext() function; you (almost) have to know the number of nodes and node names or so some silly unpythonic coding that should not pass a code review to get the data.

If I do not use force_list, I have to test the type of jbus_event_children and have two implementations if it's a str or an collections.OrderedDict. 

So if I have to use force_list on all xml files to parse, since you generally do not know that **_every_** child node will have the same structure, it seems like making the default behavior is logical.

Since the same argument has been made by many people over literally many years supported by sound logic, maybe all the other people have a point worth considering?

> So if I have to use force_list on all xml files to parse, since you generally do not know that **_every_** child node will have the same structure, it seems like making the default behavior is logical.

xmltodict is not meant to be a processor for generic XML documents not in an expected structure; use an XML parser which gives you a DOM model for that.

Rather, it's for convenient reading of XML containing structured data.  If all children were forced to be lists, it would be annoying as hell for those elements which are never lists:

* `info[0].name[0]`
* `info[0].code[0]`
* `info[0].quantity[0]`
... etc

But see #204 and use `force_list=True` if you really want this.

> If I do not use force_list, I have to test the type of jbus_event_children and have two implementations if it's a str or an collections.OrderedDict.

What you want is `force_list=['jbus_event_children']` and then you get the best of both worlds.  Of course, you can still get lists when you expect scalars, if the user sends you repeated elements where they were not supposed to.  But that's the user breaking the XML contract with you.

Why do you say that "xmltodict is not meant to be a processor for generic XML documents not in an expected structure"  based on the first line of the repo, "Python module that makes working with XML feel like you are working with JSON" kinda implies it is for generic XML documents.  I might agree with you if xmltodict provided a schema validator...

given the nature of XML, it is less likely that you know an element will never be a list.  Also, you example is not right, an element with no child elements would not be list, no one implied or said that, but you could have multiple info nodes

The data provider is not sending unexpected repeated elements, that **_is_** the contract and in some cases there are 1 child nodes, in other cases, more than 1 child node...

xmltodict doesn't implement all XML features.  It doesn't handle mixed content, for example.  It offers a simplified view of XML, to avoid you having to deal with the DOM directly. 

If you expect that a particular node could have 1 or more instances of node type "foo", then you should use `force_list=['foo']`

For an example of why it would be bad to make all child elements be lists, please see [this comment](https://github.com/martinblech/xmltodict/issues/14#issuecomment-69913281).
